Description: Digital photograph (colour); view of painted rock art on a sandstone cave wall, showing an infilled unidentified shape on a projecting piece of patinated sandstone, the surround of which has flaked off. This has left a square shaped block, infilled in brown with several round flakes chipped out of it, not easily identifiable as anthropogenic or not, though the thin vertical line scraped out of the pigment through the middle of the figure appears to be. At the top of the figure is an infilled circular disc that has been chipped away from the less intensely patinated next layer of sandstone down from the main figure. Again, it is unclear whether this shape is natural or not. Wadi Sura, Egypt. Scanned
Curator's comments: The smaller cave of two (see also 2013,2034.186-203), is about 60m from the other. Wadi Sura (also spelled Sora) is a valley on the western edge of the Gilf Kebir plateau in Egypt’s western desert. There, two shallow caves lie on the right at the entrance to the inlet, one smaller than the other and both containing rock paintings. Hans Rhotert designated the caves C and D. Cave C is the larger and contains the paintings of the famous ‘swimming’ figures inspiring those in ‘The English patient’. Cave D, which is close by, contains a single scene of cattle and archers. These caves were discovered, and the valley named, in 1933 by László Almásy. There are several other rock art sites nearby, some discovered by Almásy and Rhotert in the same year, or by P. A. Clayton in 1931, and several which have subsequently been found and documented by Giancarlo Negro, Yves Gauthier, Werner Lenz, András Zboray, Werner Lenz and others.
Acquisition name: Donated by: Trust for African Rock Art
